list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Which of the following provides evidence for a higher level of biodiversity now compared to any time in the past?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Changing levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The fossil record
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ A decrease in the rate of evolution
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Decreased levels of speciation
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The number of organisms found via the fossil record for any era is much lower compared to the number of organisms found on Earth now and those that continue to be found, so Choice B  is correct. Choice A  is incorrect as changing levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide provide evidence for humans' impact on carbon dioxide levels. Choices C and D  are incorrect as evidence suggests that the rate of evolution and speciation are increasing, which provides evidence for increasing biodiversity.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Which is not a cause of the current biodiversity crisis?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Decreased urbanisation
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The widespread use of vaccines
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Increased air travel
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Increased transmission of diseases
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Urbanisation is not decreasing, it is increasing all over the world, which is contributing to the current biodiversity crisis. Choice A  is correct.
The widespread use of vaccines has led to fewer people dying of diseases before reproductive age, contributing to worldwide population growth, which contributes to the current biodiversity crisis, so Choice B is incorrect. Increased air travel results in more pollution and makes it easier for diseases to spread worldwide which sometimes negatively impacts species, contributing to the biodiversity crisis, so Choices C and D are incorrect.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Which statement(s) are possible solutions to the biodiversity crisis?


- I.Promoting rewilding projectsII.Recycling and reusing productsIII.Increase meat consumption




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Rewilding projects attempt to restore and rehabilitate ecosystems by reintroducing native species and allowing natural processes to become re-established.  Statement I is therefore correct. Recycling and reusing products means fewer resources will be extracted from the Earth which is a process that can destroy natural habitats and lead to excessive landfill use, so Statement II is correct. Choice C  is therefore correct (Statement I and II).
Increasing meat consumption (Statement III) results in more land being cleared for animals such as cattle to be bred, decreasing biodiversity. Choice D is therefore incorrect as it includes this statement. Choices A and B are missing one of the possible solutions to the crisis and are therefore incorrect.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Which is not a cause of anthropogenic species extinction?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Overhunting
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Deforestation
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Introduction of new diseases
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Asteroids
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Anthropogenic species extinction is extinction caused by human activities.  Asteroid impacts are natural events and are not caused by human activities. However, they have played a significant role in past mass extinctions, such as the event that led to the extinction of the dinosaurs. Choice D is therefore correct.
When humans overhunt (Choice A) it can lead to a decline in populations and, in some cases, extinction. Deforestation (Choice B) is another human activity. The clearing of forests for purposes such as agriculture, logging or urban development, can destroy habitats and disrupt ecosystems, leading to extinction of species that rely on those habitats. When humans introduce new diseases to ecosystems (Choice C), either accidentally or deliberately, it can have devastating effects on native species and bring about extinction.  Choices A, B  and C  are therefore incorrect.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The image shows changes in coverage to mixed dipterocarp forests in Southeast Asia over the last 100 years.
Which is not a factor that contributed to these changes?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a1fefead-ab2a-4ce6-991b-34aa2eb33cde/images/ede73a61-24fa-43b8-b1ae-1135b7e67858/BI0904_A4.2.png)


[Source: Adapted from San Jose. (2006, February 8). File: map of east asia.png - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 10, 2023 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Map_of_East_Asia.png. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Building of new roads to mining sites
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Poaching of endangered species
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Planting of rubber plantations
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Building of hydroelectric dams
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The image shows the loss of forests in Southeast Asia over 100 years. Poaching of endangered species does not result in deforestation; Choice B  is correct.
Building new roads to mining sites involves clearing land to mine sites, so Choice A  is incorrect. Planting rubber plantations requires clearing forests to plant rubber trees, so Choice C  is incorrect.  Building hydroelectric dams can lead to flooding of forests and irreparable damage to trees, so Choice D is also incorrect.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Below is a list of conservation strategies:


- I.Establishing a zoo to breed endangered species in controlled environmentsII.National parks and protected areas where species live in their natural habitatIII.Seed banks that store genetic material from endangered plant species

Which of the statements describes an example of in-situ conservation?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is false because a zoo is an example of ex-situ conservation (when species are protected outside of their natural habitat). 
Statement II is true because a National park is an example of in-situ conservation, focusing on protecting species in their natural habitats.
Statement III is false because a seed bank is an example of ex-situ conservation.
Choice B is therefore correct as it only gives the true Statement II.
Choices A, C and D are all incorrect as they include one or more of the false Statements I and III.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Which definitions are matched to the correct form of diversity?

Ecosystem diversityGenetic diversitySpecies diversityA.$\hspace{1em}$Different habitats, communities and ecological processesThe type of alleles in a populationGenetic variation within a speciesB.$\hspace{1em}$The number of species and their abundance in an areaPhenotypic variation in a communityGenetic variability within a speciesC.$\hspace{1em}$Variety and abundance of different ecosystems in a geographical areaGenetic variability within a species or populationThe number of species and their abundance in an areaD.$\hspace{1em}$Different habitats, communities and ecological processesThe total number and type of epigenetic markers in a populationThe variety of all life on Earth
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Ecosystem diversity is defined as the variety and abundance of different ecosystems present in a geographical area. Genetic diversity is the genetic variability within a species or population. Species diversity is the number and relative abundance of species found in a specific area. Therefore Choice C is correct.
Choice A is incorrect because genetic diversity does not only refer to the type of alleles in a population but the number of different alleles in a population. Choice B  is incorrect because phenotypic variation refers to differences in observable characteristics, not genetic diversity, and the definition of ecosystem diversity shown in row B is actually the definition for species diversity. Choice D  is incorrect as genetic diversity does not relate to the control of the expression of genes (epigenetics) within a population and the variety of all life on Earth is the definition for biodiversity.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Which is the most significant factor in the loss of global biodiversity being experienced in the 21st century?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Industrialisation
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Human population growth
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Invasive plant species
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Deforestation
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because the rapid growth in human population (which has included a doubling in the period 1960-2020) has put pressure on all the Earth’s resources that humans rely upon. In doing so, habitat loss has had a major negative effect on thousands of species across all five kingdoms. 
Choices A, C and D are all incorrect; whilst they are all factors contributing to global biodiversity loss, they are not the overarching cause. The question asks for the ‘most significant factor’, which is human population growth.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The electric blue tarantula (Chilobrachys natanicharum, pictured below) is a newly-listed (2023) species found in the mangrove swamps of south-western Thailand. The vivid blue colour is created by nanostructures on the spider’s hairs that produce an iridescent effect.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2d9c8dd7-9273-4363-b0f3-46ca62fdff2e/images/3130ca0e-d70d-4ae6-9e0f-9a2d58bbfde3/BI2808.png)

The electric blue tarantula Chilobrachys natanicharum[Source: Chomphuphuang, Narin et al (2024 March, 28), File: Chilobrachys natanicharum2 [image]. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 2025 April, 30 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Chilobrachys_natanicharum2.jpg. CC BY 4.0]

Which statement about the electric blue tarantula is most likely to be correct?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The electric blue tarantula would be able to mate successfully with another tarantula found in Thailand, Chilobrachys huahini, and produce fertile offspring.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The electric blue tarantula has recently evolved from darker-coloured species of tarantula.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The electric blue tarantula was previously classified in the class Insecta (insects).
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The electric blue tarantula has existed for a long time, but was not discovered until recently.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because, like the vast majority of animal species that live on Earth today, this species had been unknown to humans. It has existed in remote areas away from human habitation, in a niche that makes it a rare global species. As such, it was not discovered until 2023, when human intervention to prevent habitat loss to palm oil farming identified the species. 
Choice A is incorrect because Chilobrachys huahini is a distinct species; only members of the same species can reproduce successfully and produce fertile offspring. 
Choice B is incorrect because there is no evidence of the recent emergence of this species; it is more likely to have been undiscovered for a long time. 
Choice C is incorrect because all spiders, including the tarantula, belong to the class Arachnida (arachnids). The key difference is the number of pairs of legs; insects have 3 pairs, whereas arachnids have 4 pairs.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
What is the main cause of Southeast Asia's loss of dipterocarp forest ecosystems?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Plantations of palm oil (Elaeis guineensis)
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Fungal disease affecting trees
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Nutrient depletion in the soil
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Anthropogenic climate change
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because palm oil plantations now cover large areas previously inhabited by dipterocarp species. Palm oil is used widely in the food and cosmetics industries.
Choice B is incorrect because, whilst fungal disease does occur in all natural rainforests, it has not caused widespread loss of dipterocarp species. 
Choice C is incorrect because soil nutrient depletion will have occurred, but as a result of biodiversity loss, not a cause of it. 
Choice D is incorrect because, whilst anthropogenic (human-caused) climate change is a cause of ecosystem loss, it is not the main cause in this case.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Which of the following has/have directly contributed to biodiversity loss?


- I.The overhunting of African elephants for their ivoryII.The expansion of cities like São Paulo, BrazilIII.The spread of the invasive zebra mussels in North America through ballast water from ships




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because overhunting is one cause of the biodiversity crisis. 
Statement II is true because urbanisation is a cause of the biodiversity crisis. 
Statement III is true because the introduction/spread of pests, diseases and alien species due to global transport are causes of the biodiversity crisis.
Therefore, Choice D is the correct answer as Statements I, II and III are true.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Which approach, carried out by conservationists in zoos and botanical gardens, defines the transition between ex-situ conservation and in-situ conservation?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Building more capacity in zoos and botanical gardens.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Carrying out artificial selection within zoos and botanical gardens.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Building the population of captive-bred species across zoos and botanical gardens in many countries.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Release of captive-bred species from zoos and botanical gardens into nature reserves.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because the transfer of ex-situ to in-situ means the return of species from captivity to areas that could become their natural habitats again. Nature reserves increase the chances of successful re-introduction, although many other measures would have to be taken to ensure success. 
Choice A is incorrect because building more captive breeding areas will not increase the chances of being able to reintroduce species back into the wild. 
Choice B is incorrect because, whilst artificial selection would allow desirable traits to be selected for in captivity, this would not necessarily guarantee that species would thrive or even survive in a wild habitat again. Artificial selection would also take a long time (measured in years and decades for some species in particular), as successive generations are bred. 
Choice C is incorrect because having more animals in captivity and plants in botanical gardens would do little to increase the chances of those species being successfully reintroduced to the wild. A large captive population serves no natural purpose to conservation unless a species is released into the wild at some stage. Keeping species in captive breeding might be called ‘preservation’, but it is not ‘conservation’ in its truest sense.

An increase in agriculture which utilises monocultures lowers species diversity in the area ($\checkmark$). An increase in the human population is also correlated with increased global transport, which can result in increased pollution, which contributes to global warming ($\checkmark$), which can have a detrimental effect on ecosystems and also can result in an increased spread of invasive species ($\checkmark$) and pests ($\checkmark$), which lowers biodiversity within ecosystems. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
The image shows Aotearoa’s (New Zealand) North Island giant moa (Dinornis novaezealandiae), which became extinct in the period 1300 - 1500 A.D.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2461d794-139c-4be6-9943-c8e721f7962d/images/dcbe8b52-91ed-4354-94f8-f2cd1432bb00/BI2809.png)


[Source: Adapted from Frederick William Frohawk (16 July 1861 - 10 December 1946). File: Dinornis novaezealandiae [image]. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 2025 April 30 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File.png. Public domain]
Which of the following factors was not a contributing factor to the extinction of the giant moa during that period?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Habitat loss caused by human encroachment
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Anthropogenic climate change
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Hunting
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Predation by non-human species
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct (not a factor in the moa’s extinction) because this is an example of anthropogenic extinction, but not a direct result of climate change. In the period 1300-1500 A.D., human-caused climate change had not yet occurred; such climate changes began to occur in the mid-20th century and have continued to the present. 
Choice A is incorrect (a factor in the moa’s extinction) because human forest clearance would have taken place to create living and farming space for humans, their crops and livestock. This will have reduced the moa’s habitat area, impacting its population.
Choice C is incorrect (a factor in the moa’s extinction) hunting by humans was the single largest factor impacting the moa’s population. They were hunted mainly as a food source for the early settlers of Aotearoa. 
Choice D is incorrect (a factor in the moa’s extinction) because the moa was not an apex predator; the Haast’s eagle (Hieraaetus moorei) was a natural predator of the moa, so it played a role in reducing the moa’s population size.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
How does introducing new invasive species, such as Japanese knotweed (Reynoutria japonica), to ecosystems affect biodiversity?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7f14db66-6918-4f41-a685-70114e0bcde6/images/01bd4d18-ba7d-4633-965b-1e169e05e1c7/BI0907.png)


[Source: Adapted from Carter, W. (2019, September 11). File: reynoutria japonica in Brastad 1.jpg - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 10, 2023 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Reynoutria_japonica_in_Brastad_1.jpg. Copyright free]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Increases biodiversity because there are more species in the ecosystem
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Decreases biodiversity as the invasive species outcompetes native species for resources
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Decreases biodiversity as new plants encourage new insects and animals to immigrate to the ecosystem
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Increases biodiversity as the invasive species brings new pests into the ecosystem
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Invasive species are species that arrive in an ecosystem to which they are not endemic to and they often lack natural population controls such as herbivores or predators.  They therefore sometimes outcompete native species for resources which can decrease biodiversity.  Choice B is correct.

Choice A is incorrect, as introducing an invasive species usually reduces biodiversity. There are many reasons for this, including competition with native species, predation, herbivory, habitat alteration and the introduction of disease. Choice C is incorrect as although new plants may encourage new insects and plants to immigrate into an area, this would increase biodiversity, not decrease it.  Choice D is incorrect because although invasive species can bring new pests, these pests often reduce biodiversity by decimating native populations.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Which species are prioritised for conservation in the EDGE of Existence programme?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Species that are genetically distinct from other living species, and are in danger of extinction.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Species that are evolutionarily distinct, and are found in vulnerable ecosystems.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Species that are closely related to keystone species, and are in danger of extinction.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Species that are keystone species, and are found in vulnerable ecosystems.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because the EDGE of Existence program highlights and focuses on species that are evolutionarily distinct with few living relatives and, therefore, represent a disproportionately high level of genetic diversity. Additionally, the EDGE of Existence program only prioritises species on the endangered and vulnerable IUCN lists, which are, therefore, in danger of extinction.
Choice B is incorrect because the EDGE of Existence program does not use vulnerable ecosystems as a criterion. It focuses solely on species that are evolutionarily distinct and threatened with extinction.
Choice C is incorrect because while keystone species play a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem structure and function, they are not necessarily evolutionarily distinct. The EDGE programme does not prioritise species based on their ecological role.
Choice D is incorrect because neither keystone species nor vulnerable ecosystems are criteria for the EDGE of Existence program.

list.content: The Eurasian beaver (Castor fiber) has been described as a species that promotes biodiversity. Beavers are herbivores that feed on freshwater plants and tree bark. [4] The effect of introducing beavers on the species diversity of birds and bats was studied in four areas: on river banks, one without any beaver activity and one where beavers are present, and then ponds, again, one without beaver activity and one where beavers were present. The graph below shows the calculated Simpson’s reciprocal index of Diversity for each area. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/536e088c-9e87-4ae5-902d-c81de6be0cb0/BI1684%20fig2.png) [©Revision Village 2024] - State two necessary measurements to calculate Simpson’s reciprocal index of diversity. [1] - Calculate the percentage increase in the species diversity of bats in the pond after the introduction of the beaver. [2] Beavers became extinct in the UK over 400 years ago. Reintroduction programmes are now being carried out in various regions of the UK. - Suggest three anthropogenic activities that could have led to the extinction of the beavers in the UK. [3]
list.markScheme: - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ many different habitats OR niches are created by beaver activity [1] $\ce{ -> }$ dams create pools that slow the run-off of rivers, benefiting plant rooting [1] $\ce{ -> }$ dams generate wetlands that harbour insect OR invertebrate species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ this promotes a food chain with consumers such as birds [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pools are habitats for aquatic plants OR fish [1] $\ce{ -> }$ felling trees allows sunlight onto the forest floor, benefiting ground-level plants and shrubs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fallen trees are a source of food for microorganisms OR detritivores [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The activity of beavers creates many habitats for other organisms ($\checkmark$), with an overall increase in biodiversity. Dams slow the run-off of rainwater which has a beneficial effect on plant roots which are not washed away by fast-flowing water ($\checkmark$). The pools also attract fish species and aquatic plants that can oxygenate the pond water ($\checkmark$); beavers do not eat fish, so there is no harm to the fish from them. - the following: $\ce{ -> }$ total number of different species in the area OR species richness AND total number of organisms of each species OR species evenness [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Two measurements needed to calculate Simpson’s Diversity Index are the total number of species in the area and the total number of organisms of each species($\checkmark$). - the following: $\ce{ -> }$ percentage increase = {(final volume - initial volume)/initial volume} $\times$ 100% [1] OR {(0.81-0.51) / 0.51} $\times$ 100% $\ce{ -> }$ 58.8% (allow numbers between 52 and 64%) [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Percentage increase = {(p.81$-$0.51) / 0.51} x 100% ($\checkmark$) = $-$58.8% ($\checkmark$) - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ hunting for fur OR castoreum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ habitat destruction OR the draining of wetlands OR other hydrological changes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ deforestation OR logging OR increase in agricultural land [1] $\ce{ -> }$ water pollution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fragmentation of landscape [1] $\ce{ -> }$ urbanisation OR industrial development OR road construction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ introduction of alien species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ trade OR travel leading to introduction of disease [1] $\ce{ -> }$ use of pesticides OR herbicides OR agricultural chemicals [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The extinction of beavers in the UK may have been caused by overhunting for their valuable fur and castoreum ($\checkmark$), combined with extensive habitat destruction due to the draining of wetlands ($\checkmark$) and deforestation for agricultural expansion ($\checkmark$). list.content:
The graph shows the global human population since 1700 CE, with a projection made to 2086.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/5e38479b-021b-42bf-9f22-5749b575d27f/QuesEdit2.png)


[© Revision Village 2025]

According to the projection, what will be the percentage population increase between 2000 and 2050 CE?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 27%
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 38%
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 62%
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 88%
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because the global human population in 2000 was 6.0 billion, projected to increase to 9.7 billion by 2050. 
The increase is:
9.7 billion − 6.0 billion = 3.7 billion
To calculate the percentage increase:
Percentage increase = ($\dfrac{\ce{increase}}{\ce{population in 2000}}) \times 100$%
= ($\dfrac{\ce{3.7 billion}}{\ce{6.0 billion}}) \times 100$% = 61.67%

list.title: Question 26
list.content: Organisms that are better adapted to their environment are more likely to survive and thrive. - Describe how the skin and mucous membranes provide both physical and chemical defence against pathogens. [4] - Explain the importance of concentration gradients and the mechanisms that regulate them in the human ventilation system. [4] - Discuss to what extent the fossil record provides evidence for evolution. [7]
list.markScheme: - any four of the following: Answer must include one point from physical defence and one point from chemical defence to gain full marks Physical defence $\ce{ -> }$ skin provides a physical barrier OR is composed of multiple tissue layers preventing pathogens from entering the body [1] $\ce{ -> }$ skin continuously sheds dead cells which removes any pathogens on the surface [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cells in skin are held together by tight junctions reinforcing the barrier function OR preventing pathogens from passing between cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mucus produced by mucous membranes can trap pathogens [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mucus containing trapped pathogens is either expelled by the body or swallowed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cilia on mucous membrane surfaces move pathogens OR foreign particles out of the body [1] Chemical defence $\ce{ -> }$ sebaceous glands in the skin secrete sebum, which lowers the pH of the skin and inhibits the growth of bacteria and fungi [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mucus contains lysozyme OR antimicrobial enzymes which break down bacterial cell walls [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sweat contains antimicrobials OR acids which inhibit growth of pathogens [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The skin provides physical defence by forming a barrier that prevents pathogens from entering the body ($\checkmark$). It also provides chemical defence against pathogens by having sebaceous glands that secrete sebum, which lowers the pH of the skin and so inhibits the growth of bacteria and fungi on the skin ($\checkmark$). Mucous membranes line the internal surfaces of some organs and body cavities and secrete mucus, which can trap pathogens ($\checkmark$). The mucus is then expelled by the body or swallowed ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ steeper the concentration gradient, the greater the rate of diffusion, allowing for faster movement of molecules from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration [1] $\ce{ -> }$ inhaled air in alveoli has a higher concentration of oxygen than oxygen-depleted blood in the capillaries surrounding the alveoli OR blood has a higher concentration of carbon dioxide than the air in the alveoli. [1] $\ce{ -> }$ concentration gradients facilitate diffusion of oxygen from alveoli into blood OR carbon dioxide from blood into alveoli, which provides cells with oxygen for respiration and removes waste carbon dioxide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ large network of capillaries surrounding alveoli rapidly transport oxygen away from the lungs OR rapidly transport carbon dioxide from the body to the lungs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the processes of inhalation and exhalation ensure that there is a constant flow of air in and out of lungs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chemoreceptors in carotid artery OR aorta OR medulla monitor blood pH levels OR blood carbon dioxide concentrations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chemoreceptors send signals to respiratory centre in medulla oblongata OR brain stem [1] respiratory centre OR medulla oblongata controls breathing rate OR depth of breathing to maintain concentration gradient of oxygen [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Efficient gas exchange in the lungs relies on maintaining concentration gradients, where inhaled air in the alveoli has a higher concentration of oxygen than oxygen-depleted blood and a lower concentration of carbon dioxide than that in the surrounding capillaries ($\checkmark$). This gradient allows oxygen to diffuse from the alveoli into the blood and carbon dioxide from the blood into the alveoli ($\checkmark$). An extensive network of capillaries surrounding the alveoli rapidly transports oxygen away from the lungs and carbon dioxide to the lungs ($\checkmark$). The processes of inhalation and exhalation ensure a constant flow of air in and out of the lungs, maintaining these gradients ($\checkmark$). Chemoreceptors in the carotid artery and aorta monitor blood pH ($\checkmark$), sending signals to the respiratory centre to adjust breathing rate and depth ($\checkmark$). - Aay seven of the following: Answer must include one answer from ‘provides evidence’ and one answer from ‘doesn’t provide’ evidence to gain full marks Provides evidence $\ce{ -> }$ some organisms have very good fossil records, which allow their evolution to be tracked easily, e.g. horses [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the sequence of fossils that appear in layers of rock matches the sequence in which they would be expected to evolve [1] $\ce{ -> }$ older organisms appear in deeper rock layers OR strata, and more recently evolved organisms appear in the upper layers [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there are fossils of extinct organisms with transitional forms OR fossils of extinct organisms that have features that link different stages of evolution, e.g. Archaeopteryx, bird-like dinosaurs that support the hypothesis that birds evolved from reptiles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the fossil record shows evidence of mass extinction events OR there are many more extinct species than living ones [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fossils show evidence of adaptive radiation OR divergence of different organisms from a common ancestor OR speciation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the fossil record shows evidence of vestigial structures that are no longer present in current organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is fossil evidence for the existence of the last universal common ancestor (LUCA) near hydrothermal vents [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fossils provide chronological evidence that supports the theory of gradualism in evolution, where small changes accumulate over long periods [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fossilised remains of early hominids show a clear progression in brain size OR bipedalism, supporting human evolution [1] Doesn’t provide evidence $\ce{ -> }$ fossil record is incomplete, with many gaps OR some fossil species appear abruptly in the fossil record without any precursors [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some species in the fossil record appear not to have changed much over long periods of time [1] $\ce{ -> }$ convergent evolution OR fossils of unrelated organisms with similar features makes it difficult to track evolution accurately [1] $\ce{ -> }$ soft-bodied organisms are rarely fossilised, leading to an incomplete record that skews our understanding of evolutionary history [1] $\ce{ -> }$ process of fossilisation is rare and biased towards certain environments, meaning that the fossil record may not accurately represent all ecosystems and organisms [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The fossil record supports evolution because some organisms have well-documented fossil records that allow their evolutionary changes to be tracked easily ($\checkmark$). Additionally, the sequence in which fossils appear in rock layers matches the sequence in which they would be expected to evolve ($\checkmark$). For example, older organisms are found in deeper layers of rocks, while more recently evolved organisms are found in the upper layers ($\checkmark$). There are also fossils of extinct organisms with transitional features, such as Archaeopteryx, a bird-like dinosaur, which supports the hypothesis that birds evolved from reptiles and provides evolutionary links between present and extinct species ($\checkmark$). However, there are gaps in the fossil record ($\checkmark$), some species appear not to have changed over long periods of time ($\checkmark$), and convergent evolution can make it difficult to track evolution accurately ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.
